abstract.skos:scopeNote: A relationship based on intellectual exchange
A link between persons.
A relationship between a teacher and a student.
A "relationship" constituted by one person dedicating an intellectual work to another whether or not the two individuals knew each other
A "relationship" constituted by one person citing the written work of another.
A relationship (real or metaphorical) between a person who is said to follow the ideas of another person.
A "relationship" constituted by one person reading the written work of another without necessarily citing its contents.
A "relationship" constituted by one person attempting to refute the work of another without necessarily citing that person
A connection between any real world entities.
Used to indicate when distinct entities share a location and therefore might be confused.
A relationship between a person and an object damaged or destroyed by that person.
Used to distinguish between entities that have been confused in the scholarly literature or might be confused by users.
Used for entities identified as distinct but where information is scant and there is a possibility that they might actually be identical.
An unspecified relationship between events.
Used to indicate when places share a name but remain distinct; i.e. when different settlements or churches share a name.
Used to indicate when a place entity is closely related conceptually to another, i.e. a settlement, its diocese, and its region.
A casual relationship between acquaintances that does nor rise to the level of friendship.
A relationship between people involved in some kind of an alliance.
A relationship in which a person expresses enmity for another.
A relationship persons who are part of the same extended household.
A relationship within informant networks.
Friendship between persons.
A sexual relationship between people.
A relationship between persons in an unspecified kinship relationship, including either a relationship of affinity or consanguinity.
A relationship between that is of a professional nature.
Used with closely related events such as meaningful close proximity, cause and effect, part to whole, etc.
Used to note that different entities or references speak about the same event.
A relationship between someone who persecutes another person, generally but not necessarily with legal sanction
A relationship between someone who sent a letter and the person to whom it was addressed.
A relationship between a freed slave and the person who used to enslave them.
A relationship between an enslaver and the person they enslave.
A relationship between two or more persons who are part of the same household.
A relationship constituted by one person conveying knowledge about another person in an oral setting.
A relationship constituted by one person conveying knowledge to another person in an oral setting.
A "relationship" constituted by one person conveying knowledge about another person through writing.
A relationship between a person and any group of persons that includes that individual.
Used for formerly enslaved persons who attained their freedom.
A relationship between an enslaver and their domestic slave.
A "relationship" constituted by one person citing negatively the written work of another.
A "relationship" constituted by one person citing positively the written work of another.
A relationship between colleagues who work in the same institution or are funded by the same patron.
A "relationship" constituted by one person reading the handwriting of another.
A casual sexual relationship between people.
A sexual relationship between people this is deemed serious due to duration, level of commitment, etc.
A relationship between two persons who are part of the same family.
A sexual relationship that is recognized in law
A relationship between persons with a legally and/or socially binding marriage contract.
A relationship between two or more persons who are part of the same extended family.
A relationship between parents, children, and siblings.
An ancestor of a person when the relationship is either very distant in time and/or the specific relationship is unknown.
The child of a sibling of a person, used for an aunt/uncle and neice/nephew relationships.
The cousin of a person.
The descendant of a person when the relationship is either very distant in time and/or the specific relationship is unknown.
A relationship a person and the sibling of the parent of a person, used in aunt/uncle and niece/nephew situations.
The child of a person.
The parent of a person.
A relationship between persons who share parents; use one or more qualifier relationships to indicate adoption, half, etc.
A parent of one's parent.
The grandparent of one's parent.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a family relationship was acknowledged by the parties.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a familial relationship was constituted by adoption.

A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a relationship was alleged. This can be used to indicate a slander of one's opponents, i.e. "Adherents of the Council of Chalcedon are followers of Nestorius."
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a family relationship was claimed by some source.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a familial relationship was constituted through fostering.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a family relationship was a half relationship instead of a full relationship, i.e. half-sibling.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a family relationship was constituted through marriage.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating indicating that a family connection was matrilineal.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating indicating that a family connection was patrilineal.
A "qualifier relationship" indicating that a family relationship was constituted through remarriage.
A relationship between the carrier of a letter and the person who sent the letter.
A relationship between the carrier of a letter and the person to whom they delivered the letter.
A relationship between people engaged together in a professional activity.
A professional relationship defined by military service.
A relationship between a patron and a client; can be formal or informal.
A relationship constituted by one person paying another for services.
A relationship between people by virtue of their involvement in a judicial act.
A relationship constituted by one or more of the participants' religious position; does not pertain to any specific religion.
A "relationship" constituted by a person honoring another in a ritual (civic, religious, etc.); i.e. includes their name in the dyptichs of the church or reads out their name as part of the liturgy.
A relationship constituted by two or more people partaking together in the Eucharist.
A relationship between someone who hears the confession of another person and that other person
A relationship between people in a monastic setting
A relationship with familial significance but established through a ritual act.
A relationship between a member of the clergy and a person baptized by that clergy person.
A relationship between a bishop and a person under his ecclesiastical authority if that person was either laity or whose clerical status is unknown.
A relationship between any religious official and a person served by that religious official, not specific to any particular religion; used to describe something like "Person x is my rabbi".
A relationship between clergy of the same religious community.
A relationship between someone performing a rite that bestows religious authority and the person being ordained.
Used to describe individuals or parties being in communion with one another; i.e. taking the eucharist together.
A relationship between people living together in monastic community.
A relationship between the head of a monastery (abbess/abbot/etc.) and a member of that person's monastery.
A relationship between a bishop and a one or more bishops under his ecclesiastical authority, as in a patriarch or metropolitan bishop.
A relationship between a bishop and one or more members of the clergy over whom he exercises authority.
A relationship between a bishop and one or more monks over whom he exercises authority.
A relationship constituted by a person exercising military command over another.
A relationship between a person who brought legal charges against another person in a civil, criminal, or ecclesiastical matter.
A relationship between someone seeking a legal ruling and the authority to whom that person submitted a petition.
Collects the relationships that will take @active and @passive attributes when used in the TEI.
Collects the relationships that will take a @mutual attribute when used in the TEI.
A relationship between a baptismal sponsor and the person being baptized.
A brother relationship established through religious ritual.
Used for administrative structures and mechanisms of any type of organization, including but not limited to states, churches, and monasteries.
Used for those who had completed the school of the grammarians.
Used for "doorkeepers" in imperial or other elite households; often a position of considerable influence.
Used for those acting as guardians or regents of another.
Used for priests to whom a bishop had delegated the authority to oversee rural clergy.
Used for members of a body of priests who acted as advisors to their bishop.
Used for the chief physician to the emperor
Used to indicate women who dress as men in a monastic context so as to pursue the monastic experience of men.
Used for rural bishops with authority over a geographic range that did not include a metropolis or large settlement.
Used for a close advisor to a Christian bishop.
A named place concept that merges multiple distinct place types, such as a city and a diocese. More specific types are preferred.
A military outpost such as a fort or a castle.
A land-mass smaller than a continent surrounded on all sides by water.
A place whose name is known, but what sort of place it represents is unknown.
Any collection of civilian residences, from the smallest village to the largest metropolis.
An area with artificial boundaries which is not necessarily built up, such as a cemetery, town square, or polo ground.
A natural feature for which there is no narrower category, such as a mountain or open water. Examples of this type include forests and hot springs.
A subdivision of an urban center.
A term indicating a geographic extent larger than a city, without a corresponding politico-administrative apparatus. The size could range from a small valley to an entire continent.
A sovereign government such as an empire, kingdom, caliphate, or independent emirate.
A construction for which there is no narrower category, such as a church or mosque. Examples of this type include palaces and named city gates.
A broad category for seas, lakes, oceans, and ponds.
The place type values used in The Syriac Gazetteer.
A building for Christian religious services. It can be a parish church, a monastic church, a cathedral, or a small chapel used only occasionally, but not a chapel that is part of a larger church.
A building or designated space for instruction in the Islamic sciences.
A building designated for use in Jewish worship.
A building designated for use in "pagan" or traditional worship.
A whole monastic complex, including living quarters for the monks or nuns, the church(es), and potentially a refectory, library, school, or other part.
An elevated physical feature, from Mt. Ararat down to a prominent hill.
A stream of water of whatever size, from the smallest creek to the Amazon. Wadis are also included, even if they are not filled with water year-round.
An ecclesiastical region below a diocese, presided over by a priest.

A political unit subject to a "state" but larger than a city. States often have multiple levels of administrative units (e.g. the late Ottoman vilayets, sanjaks, kazas, and nahiyes), all of which can be indicated as a "province."
An ecclesiastical province governed by a bishop, archbishop, or metropolitan.

title.skos:prefLabel: Primary Sources [Old French], in Old French
Primary Sources [Old German], in Old German
Primary Sources [Old French], with Dutch Translation
Primary Sources [Old French], with English Translation
Primary Sources [Old French], in English Translation
Primary Sources [Old French], in Dutch Translation

abstract.skos:scopeNote: Used for the head deacon of a church or bishopric
Used for when a leader enters an office follow the end of their predecessors term; the office can be political, religious, etc.
Used for probationary periods such as a period of testing before being admitted to the monastic life.
Used for verbal or written interactions in which one person denounces another and calls them to some kind of reform or repentance.
Used for verbal or written interactions in which one person insults another.
Used for loan words brought into Syriac from other languages.
Used for Arabic influences on Aramaic, specifically Syriac.
Used for the dwelling places of hermits/anchorites; can be a cave, built environment, etc.
Used for introductions to Syriac literature and the field of Syriac Studies
Used for studies on the titles of works.
Used for the transmission of texts, text corpora, etc.
Used for the Jewish backgrounds to Syriac literature.
A genre used to describe works that deal with a broad range of topics.
Used for Old Testament law in general as well as specific subsets of that law such as the Ten Commandments.
Used for philosophical and theological discussions of the nature of a being, human or divine.
Used for the idea that Adam had a contract with Death giving the latter authority of the human race.
Used to indicate feminine imagery in depictions of the Christian God.
Used for the human body as a microcosm of a larger entity or entities.

Used to indicate circumstances where a historical person or group deemed a set of theological ideas, one or more groups, or one or more individuals to be incompatible with their own beliefs and practices. Use of this concept should not be construed an affirmation or denial of any particular theology.
Used for institutions that possess judicial power and render judgements regarding civil and criminal matters.
Used for proceedings in which judgment is rendered; esp. in a legal or ecclesiastical setting.
Used of people who seize power in an institution in an unorthodox or extra-legal way.
Used to describe certain court officials, the term originally referred to the quartermaster of a camp, "castrum."
Used for a Roman tax official
Used for persons holding this high diplomatic office in the imperial administration
Used for the person in charge of the running of the imperial household.
Used for preferred ways that individuals and groups refer to themselves.
Used for troubling thoughts that lead one's mind away from God; esp. in an ascetic or monastic context.
Used for anyone in charge of the cellar; esp. but not exclusively in a monastic setting.
Used for Persian military commanders holding this title.
A relationship based on two or more people co-authoring a document.
A collection of concepts for categories of people typically considered holy. This is used in the SPEAR schema customization to constrain markup in certain contexts.
This is a broad category used for practitioners of traditional religions of the ancient Mediterranean, Near East, etc.
